awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Photometric redshifts via Bayesian functional data analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Many projects mapping the sky require precise estimates of the speed at which galaxies are receding.  A wide-spread technique derives this number, the redshift, from carefully measuring galaxy colors, using an analysis called "photo-zs".  Unfortunately, current estimation methods are not precise enough to achieve major survey science goals.  The present team of astronomers and statisticians will improve both the precision and the reliability of photo-zs.  This work will provide key enabling technology for large surveys in progress and in development, which represent a considerable investment in astronomy.  This project will increase the return on that investment.  The research requires innovation in both astronomy and statistics and the development of new statistical methods likely to have significant additional impact.  The research will help to train a diverse population of students and postdocs in advanced statistics via summer schools and other special sessions, and historically, many such trainees have gone on to pursue careers in data science.

Current and forthcoming automated digital sky surveys aim to push further into "precision cosmology" territory by meticulously mapping the distribution and properties of hundreds of millions of galaxies, and measuring the details of thousands of supernovae.  This requires accurate and precise estimation of the redshifts of galaxies using broad-band photometric data, by the technique known as photometric redshifts, or photo-zs for short.  Unfortunately, current estimation methods do not enable the most complete science return from these surveys.  The present project unites astronomers and statisticians to improve the precision as well as the reliability of photo-zs, by modeling spectral energy distributions of galaxies, using Bayesian functional data analysis (FDA), an approach that emphasizes predictive modeling and thorough propagation of information and uncertainty across hierarchical, multi-stage discovery chains.  The project will use a modular, hierarchical modeling framework and account for similarity and diversity, with both conventional parameterizations, and new data-driven parameterizations.  Because this framework will produce probabilistic photo-z estimates, with possibly complex uncertainties, the team will also study how optimally to provide such estimates and to use them for cosmological science.  Open-source implementations of their algorithms will be accelerated by graphics processing units where appropriate.  The research will provide valuable inter-disciplinary training to a graduate student, while developing new statistical methods by innovatively combining FDA, machine learning, and high-performance computing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In the late 1920s, Belgian priest Georges Lemaitre and American astronomer Edwin Hubble independently discovered what we today call the Hubble-Lemaitre law: Over large scales, galaxies move away from each other with velocity proportional to distance. It revealed that the universe is expanding, implying that in the past it was denser and hotter. Extrapolating back in time, the early universe must have been incredibly dense and hot---what we today call the Big Bang. The Hubble-Lemaitre law was the first observational evidence for the Big Bang.

The Hubble-Lemaitre law is important to astronomers for another, more utilitarian reason. It is very hard to measure the distances to galaxies. In contrast, it is easier to measure the velocity with which they recede from the Milky Way. Flipping around the Hubble-Lemaitre law, we can use measurements of recession velocity to infer distances to galaxies, enabling us to map out the spatial distribution of galaxies, and to estimate physical properties of galaxies that depend on knowing distance, such as luminosity, size, and mass.

The best galaxy velocity measurements rely on spectroscopy---measuring the intensity of light as a function of wavelength. Thanks to the Doppler effect, a source of light changes color depending on its relative motion; it appears bluer if it moves toward an observer, and redder if it moves away. The effect is imperceptible in daily life because its magnitude depends on how fast an object moves compared to the speed of light. But galaxies at great separations recede from each other with large velocities, and the effect can be measured. Since recession causes colors to redden, the effect is called redshift.

The gold standard for measuring redshift is spectroscopic redshift, using detailed spectroscopy to measure the locations of spectral lines, sharp features in a galaxy's spectrum whose wavelength at rest is known. The ratio of the observed wavelength to the known rest-frame wavelength will be larger than one for receding galaxies; that excess is used to measure redshift, and conventionally denoted by z.

Unfortunately, spectroscopic redshift measurement requires spreading light out in wavelength, making it feasible only for brighter galaxies, and with time- and labor-intensive observations. Astronomers have spectroscopic redshifts for only a tiny fraction of observable galaxies.

To get around this, astronomers exploit cruder measures of the spread of light with color. Photometry refers to measuring the intensity of light through a colored filter, corresponding to a broad region of the spectrum. With photometric measurements in several filters, astronomers can measure overall colors of galaxies, say, by comparing the amount of light captured through green and red filters. A galaxy's photometric redshift (photo-z) is determined by measuring how much redder it appears than it would appear at rest.

In practice, photo-z estimation is challenging because galaxies have very diverse spectra and luminosities. Some galaxies are intrinsically redder and dimmer than others, so if we see a galaxy that looks red, we don't know if it is a bright blue galaxy at high redshift (large distance and velocity), or a dim red galaxy nearby.

The main goal of this project was to find a way to use multiple color measurements to estimate the underlying spectrum of a galaxy. This would be impossible if galaxy spectra were extremely diverse. But in fact there is limited variety among galaxy spectra. If we could find just a few numbers that can label the possible types of spectra, it becomes possible to use just a few color measurements to know a galaxy's true color, and thus determine how redshifted it is.

The team used advanced statistical and machine learning techniques to construct a new few-parameter model for galaxy spectra. The construction has three main components, depicted in the figure. First, training data with noisy and incomplete measurements of thousands of galaxy spectra are analyzed together using a new, flexible spectrum population model to provide smooth and complete spectra. Next, a machine learning technique called manifold learning arranges the spectra according to how similar they are, identifying a three-dimensional surface in the space of all possible spectra that captures the limited diversity of galaxy spectra. Finally, a new inverse map algorithm builds a function that takes the three-dimensional labels and recreates the full original spectra. This new function forms the core of a new photo-z estimation algorithm.

An overarching theme of the project was use of advanced statistical and machine learning methods in astronomy, and the project team was interdisciplinary, including astronomers, statisticians, and an applied mathematician. The project supported the statistician team members to develop new statistical methods in biology and other areas. The team engaged in training young astronomers in advanced statistics and machine learning methods, lecturing annually at the Summer School in Statistics for Astronomers hosted by Penn State University. The project trained a statistics PhD student who is now an assistant professor.
